summary: I'm picturing Taryon in his bed, very old, talking to Vex. They talk about their children and grandchildren (he and Lawrence...
body:
I’m picturing Taryon in his bed, very old, talking to Vex. They talk about their children and grandchildren (he and Lawrence adopted, after Tary retired from active adventuring), about their days in Vox Machina together, and the adventures they had after Tary left the group.

“Do you have any regrets,” Vex asks.

“Only that I didn’t meet Percy before you did,” Tary says, and as they share a laugh the sun catches his hair just right, and the gold shines through the silver that overtook it years ago.

“I hated you so much when we met you,” she says.

“I know. I deserved it.”

“But I love you now, old friend.”

“I know. I deserve that, too.” And they smile through their tears. Tary’s eyes begin to flutter, and she clasps his hand so tightly.

“Oh, little elf girl.” It’s barely a whisper. “I’ll tell your brother hello for you.” And Tary’s eyes close, one last time.

And perhaps it’s only her imagination, but Vex'ahlia hears the beating of a raven’s wings.

summary: It's really not that deep but... Caduceus left the room that had [a fucking dragon] only when he saw that Caleb had arrived, was...
body:
It’s really not that deep but… Caduceus left the room that had [a fucking dragon] only when he saw that Caleb had arrived, was capable of escaping and had made sure Caleb knew. And that thing with Fjord disappearing and Caduceus being [completely] unbothered by it and instead focusing on Caleb’s special interest? Boy howdy does it set him up as a character.

We get to see him as selfish. He cares for the Nein, yes. But none of them reached out to him the way Caleb did? None have “accepted” him the way he did. To the point where Caleb quite literally put his life on the line by giving him the periapt. Told him that they were his destiny, a promise that to a man like Caduceus probably meant more than intended. To the point that Caduceus wants to get Caleb to [his] destiny. 

Yes, he’s had good moments with Jester. Yes, they’re close. Yes, he cares for her. But Caduceus barely knows anything about this new world except that Caleb Widogast loves books and wants to keep Caduceus alive.

summary: So I just realized I hit the milestone of my first 100 a while ago and I never did anything to celebrate it. So here we go: if...
body:
So I just realized I hit the milestone of my first 100 a while ago and I never did anything to celebrate it. So here we go: if anyone wants little fics or headcanons or poems or meta on a particular moment or something, leave it in my inbox and I’ll work on them throughout the week!

And thank y’all for following my dinky little CR sideblog. I love you all.

And thank y’all for following my dinky little CR sideblog. I love you all.

And thank y’all for following my dinky little CR sideblog. I love you all.

blog.name: probablyurbanfantasyrpgideas
blog.title: Vampires And Cities Oh My
blog.description: Vampires and apartment buildings. Werewolves and skyscrapers. Faeries and courtrooms.

body:
Critical Role Urban Fantasy Headcanons

For campaign one

  • Vax: The twins’ mom had no idea about the magical world, their father lived full time in the Fae Realm. After their mom was killed by a rogue dragon, they decided to become monster hunters a la Supernatural style.
  • Vex: Trinket is the name of her car, which she has a borderline unhealthy love of. She’s great at talking their way into places, patching her brother up, and sharpshooting.
  • Keyleth: The Ashari are tasked with guarding the boundaries between the mortal world and magical world, rather than the elemental planes.
  • Percival: The de Rolo’s are members of the royal family but had no clue about the magic world until they were slaughtered by Vampires. The deal he made with Orthax was to escape and understand the magic world, not to learn how to build firearms.
  • Scanlan: He came from the Fae Realm, where he was relatively average, and decided to build a successful music career in the mortal world because it ‘would be easier there.’ He’s a very popular YouTuber now who posts pranking and singing videos.
  • Pike: Her whole family belonged to a nonmagical gang, but she wanted more. She went to a medical school, but dropped out when she discovered her magical talents for healing people.
  • Grog: A member of a rival gang, although the Strongjaw Gang did have magical ties. He and his brothers had captured a supposed member of the Trickfoot Gang, but Grog decided to show mercy and was kicked out because of it.

reblog.comment:

blog.name: trickyjesters
blog.title: take a chance, roll the dice
blog.description: Hi, I'm Ina, they/them, lvl 24 queer disaster, and apparently a warlock of Taliesin Jaffe helping him spread conspiracies. Welcome to my D&D/Critical Role sideblog. Please grab a healing potion and enjoy your stay. Watch out for the spoilers though; they're usually tagged, but they're sneaky lil things so you never know. This blog mostly runs on queue so replies might take a while. (I follow as frostbann; personal/fandom blog is voidblessed)

tags: i swear making an honest mistake on this hellsite is like inviting the hounds of hell on a hunt with yourself as the target
i know y'all mean well but. i literally can't change anything about this now
summary: Again, in a separate post: We have proof that the post I saw about Taliesin being 5′3 was mistaken. I’m sorry for spreading...
body:
Again, in a separate post: We have proof that the post I saw about Taliesin being 5′3 was mistaken. I’m sorry for spreading misinformation, and deleted the post now. Unfortunately, that’s the best I can do, it had been shared a lot already and will continue to circulate. :/ Again, I apologize!

(Also, I’d appreciate it if you would stop sending me messages that I’m wrong. I’m aware, and all you do is make me anxious, so please, just. Don’t. Thank you.)

(Also, I’d appreciate it if you would stop sending me messages that I’m wrong. I’m aware, and all you do is make me anxious, so please, just. Don’t. Thank you.)

tags: apparently this week I'm becoming the Keyleth defense squad as a way to procrastinate on my lesson planning
summary: Apparently I’m on a “defending Keyleth” kick recently, because another annoying and baseless thing that always comes up from...
body:
Apparently I’m on a “defending Keyleth” kick recently, because another annoying and baseless thing that always comes up from dudes trying to prove they have a “logical” or “objective” reason to hate on Marisha is the claim “she’s a bad player because she doesn’t know her abilities/read her spells”. But that is also a terrible take, because:

  1. Every. Single. Player. On CritRole has moments of forgetting what their spells/abilities do. Often. Love it or hate it, that they are busy people who aren’t constantly thinking about D&D rules is a part of the show. That certain people notice it more with Marisha has way more to do with a) Druid being one of the more difficult classes to play, b) Keyleth having comparably powerful abilities which had more consequences if read wrong, and c) Them deciding that Marisha is “bad” in advance and therefore noticing her mistakes more.
  2. The example they always pull out, the Wind Walk in Combat Incident, was a case of Marisha, and Taliesin and Matt ALL reading that spell wrong. And it was hilarious. 

Trying to cover up bias and sexism with this “reasoning” is so transparent. And honestly to me just makes it seem like these people have never played the game before. Or, they’ve played super boring games where everyone is an encyclopedia of rules and spells and no one ever messes up ever and everything always goes perfectly. And that sounds like the most boring D&D imaginable.

reblog.comment:
Apparently I’m on a “defending Keyleth” kick recently, because another annoying and baseless thing that always comes up from dudes trying to prove they have a “logical” or “objective” reason to hate on Marisha is the claim “she’s a bad player because she doesn’t know her abilities/read her spells”. Trying to cover up bias and sexism with this “reasoning” is so transparent. And honestly to me just makes it seem like these people have never played the game before. Or, they’ve played super boring games where everyone is an encyclopedia of rules and spells and no one ever messes up ever and everything always goes perfectly. And that sounds like the most boring D&D imaginable.

blog.name: shygaladriel
blog.title: Shy Flutterings
blog.description: Mellon nin, mae govannen

summary:
When Pike was gone she left her love and they never felt alone. 
When Scanlan was gone he left his scorn and they felt all alone...
body:
When Pike was gone she left her love and they never felt alone.

When Scanlan was gone he left his scorn and they felt all alone even with each other.
